title: Are Amish racists? - Quora
tags: Racism in the United States of America

response.answer_text: Not exactly. They reflect the world view of the Swiss and other European Anabaaptists from hundreds of years ago. While I am sure that some are racists, most of them are not so much racist as simply had no little to contact with people from other parts of the world and did not really know what to think of them. In general, their view of the world is pacifist and does not, unlike other religious groups, permit them to be violent or acting out, and they simply keep separate from ‘English’ people for religious reasons. The ‘superiority’ that Mr. Vogel put on them is generally about spiritual matters and is akin to the superiority one feels when one believes oneself to be living a decent life as God intended while others are not and must be avoided simply to avoid temptation. The separateness from others is to avoid being pulled into a sinful life. At the same time they are supposed to not be ‘proud’ and that is the inner conflict one faces, not one of smug outward arrogance, but a built-in religious conflict - to live decently and to be in a sense ‘saved’ while still being humble and ‘plain.’ Some years ago one of my Amish friends leaned over and whispered to me that one of his customers for his welding shop was “Jewish.” He looked around furtively. I don’t know if this would have upset his wife or the local bishop, but he whispered it. I said I grew up with many Jewish people and I thought they were wonderful decent people, and that my first boss was Jewish and very kind to us young workers. He smiled and relaxed, and said he felt they were ‘good decent people’ too. In general I was given a fascinating window into the world of the Amish when I spoke with them. For example at one point the crew building my barn got a huge delivery of lumber. The driver shouted, ‘Who’s in charge here?!’ and not one would step forward, because they are supposed to be humble and not put themselves above others, even if they are, in truth the leader of the construction crew. They all stood, frozen, awkward, while the driver shouted, ‘Come on, which one of you is the boss?’ The one English on their crew said ‘Don’t look at me.’ Finally the driver shouted ‘Joe Fisher signed this, where’s Joe Fisher!???’ and Joe reluctantly stepped forward. Then the driver shouted, ‘You oughta have more confidence in yourself!’ What a bizarre and uncomfortable scene that was. How badly most people who work with them fail to understand them. Another example was when I asked one of the builders to come to my barn to deal with some loose boards. As I drove him home after he did the work, he said quite simply and matter-of-factly, that an Amish woman had been killed near the spot we just passed on the road. He described the accident as the horse ‘took the ditch’ and the woman, in a panic, jumped from the buggy, struck her head on the pavement and was killed. I said that was very sad and must have hurt many people deeply. Then in not so many words (I can’t recall exactly what we said at that moment), he made me understand that he was profoundly saddened by her death, but that his religion required him not to mourn or express this feelings openly, because that is taken as ‘pride’ and questioning the wisdom of God.

I would not use the word racist to describe their bigotry. The Amish have little to no exposure to anyone who is not white and when they do, they tend to lump them into the same category as everyone else: not Amish. Non-white people are a novelty for sure and you’ll see the children staring rudely (the idea that staring is rude is not taught to the Amish), but they won’t place black non-Amish people below white non-Amish people, at least in practice. The Amish are one of the most bigoted groups of people you will ever meet. They are taught from birth that they are innately superior to all non-Amish. This is so innate that I’ve spoken to people who left the Amish who told us that they constantly had to fight that feeling of superiority that they have over everyone else, even though they know in their head that it isn’t true, they still, deep down, feel superior. So you have an insular, split away group with their own subculture, horribly inbred with genetic problems that believes that they are innately superior to all other humans. It’s not strictly racism, but it certainly isn’t any better. Because they aren’t in positions of power and their bigotry doesn’t seek to harm others, everyone leaves them alone, but it doesn’t make their bigotry any less wrong.

upvoters.user_id: Thomas de La Marnierre (トマ・サレ)

response.answer_text: I’m sure there are some Amish who are racists. There are also some Methodists who are racists. And there are Catholics who are racist, too. You can’t make a blanket statement about an entire group of people and expect it to be true. It’s worth pointing out that the Amish live in insular communities. They were founded in Europe in the late seventeenth century. Relatively few outsiders are interested in joining them because of their unusual lifestyle. That means that most Amish today have Amish ancestry that goes back hundreds of years. They are nearly all of Germanic descent. Living in an ethnically homogeneous, isolated community has a tendency to make you distrust the rest of the world, especially people who look different from you. However, Amish beliefs help to balance this out. One of their most important teachings is the value of humility (they call it Demuth, the German word). The Amish are paranoid that others would see them as being proud. That would rule out racism among the Amish in theory. I’m sure there are individual Amish here and there who are racist, though. For a point of reference, I know a black conservative Mennonite woman, and I’ve been told that she has been the victim of racism. However, this is not the way most Mennonites treat her. Mennonites on the whole are very anti-racist and are concerned about their public image. They do not tolerate open racism among them. This should be true of the Amish as a whole, too.

The Amish are not super comfortable with outsiders - any outsiders. Now what a lot of people don’t know is that the Amish do quite a bit of adopting of children. It is not rare that they adopt children of other races! They favor large families, like anything less than 5 children is too small and if they have any fertility problems getting the family size they want might be a struggle. Also, the Amish are aware that they tend to be a bit inbred and since their lifestyle makes it unadvisable to convert people to being Amish the best bet is to take in small children who can be raised in the lifestyle. Marrying outsiders has a very low success rate. Pics can be had to get because the Amish don’t go much for pictures, or the internet. It is easier to find non white Mennonite pictures on the internet. The Amish and adoption - Delaware Gazette None of this means the Amish are devoid of racism.

Jeffrey Martin’s answer is pretty accurate. Amish (and Old Order Mennonites) as a whole are a bit suspicious of “outsiders,” which causes some to associate blacks, Hispanics, men with jewelry or long hair, etc. with “city folk” or criminals, since most Amish live in rural, predominantly white areas. That said, most are opposed to the idea of racism due the teachings of the New Testament. A few families in our Old Order Mennonite group have adopted black or Hispanic children. Sadly, there are a few Amish and Mennonites with racist views.

They are deeply religious and harbour no malice towards anyone. They try to live humbly as possible. Years ago there was a man who went on a shooting spree and killed nine children in their Amish school. The response from the Amish was that they were praying for him everyday. These people are devote. Racism is never going to be part of the Amish way of life.  I’m a hard Atheist but I have nothing but respect for those people.
As Christians, they better not be. We all are God's children and the color of our skin isn't important. However, the love in our hearts is.

Are Americans racist? Yes of course some are, there will always be racist people in this world.Same goes with the Amish,as being Amish myself I would say I have come across a few Amish that might have been racist but most Amish are very respectful people and believe all people are created equal.
Amish are probably, in general, the politest people on Earth. With them, the issue is more likely to be that you don’t follow their religion than that your skin looks different from theirs.
They don’t pretend diversity is a strength to avoid being called a “racist.” Only Whites evolved the ability to pretend diversity is a strength.
